awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Miniature Low-Cost Vibration Tags and Computing Infrastructure for Identifying Marine Animal Sounds
awd_abstract_narration:
With the advent of large-scale marine passive acoustic studies it has become clear that the sources of the majority of biological sounds is not known. Knowledge of sound sources is important because sound can provide a robust measurement of biological activity, such as the distribution of spawning fishes, many of which like the cods and groupers are commercially important. It is very difficult to identify acoustic cues produced by fishes because many of them only make sounds during specific behaviors such as territoriality, aggression, courtship, and spawning and at night. Video technology has limitations in that it requires light and being in the right place at the right time. Innovative tags based on miniature accelerometers will be developed to capture sounds from marine animals. Newly recorded sounds will be deposited in the open, online infrastructure of the Macaulay Library of Natural Sounds, and the submission process will be streamlined to encourage similar use of this free repository. By creating computing infrastructure that enables sharing, this project will build a system that enables a self-sustaining community-driven solution to the science problem. These miniature tags will enable broader research into the motion of small structures and additional animals at minimal cost. This project will support the career of three young scientists and a postdoctoral research scientist. 

This project will develop and test a suite of inexpensive miniature accelerometer recorders that can be implanted or attached externally to fish, and develop an online system capable of storing data from thousands of these sensors. The three tag designs will address trade-offs between data storage, power, and tag size. The data storage tag will use a microSD card to store raw data. The acoustic transmission tag will transmit raw accelerometer data on an ultrasonic frequency that is received and decoded by a passive acoustic recorder. The micro-tag will be the smallest, lowest power tag, that will have triggered recordings to save likely signals. The data storage and micro-tags will have a mechanism for external attachment and releasing the tag, which will float to the surface for recovery. The project will produce inexpensive acceleration tags and computing infrastructure to advance knowledge of underwater sound sources.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Mooney 2022 NSF Outcomes

We are in the midst of a biodiversity crisis, with species rapidly going extinct and entire ecosystems, including and especially tropical coral reef ecosystems, struggling to keep up with rapid climate-driven environmental changes. These rapid changes call for new methods that enable monitoring and potential interventions at scale. This project has developed new technologies for discovering the natural acoustic repertoires of fish and invertebrates and thus enabling cheap, large-scale acoustic ecosystem monitoring. The project has developed and tested two kinds of tags for this purpose, both leveraging high sample rate accelerometers to tap into the body-borne vibrations associated with sound production in tagged fish.

One version is an archival tag that stores all raw data on the tag during deployment and eventually has to be retrieved to recover and analyze data. Storage of raw data enables analysis of both sound production as well as activity and movement patterns of the tagged animal, and thus allows for understanding variation in acoustic features, changes in sound use relative to external variation, and behavioral context of different communication signals, among other aspects. Due to the need for tag retrieval, this tag is particularly useful for highly territorial animals or for animals in labs or semi-enclosed research areas. A second, smaller version is a smart acoustic tag that leverages onboard machine learning to detect loud, prolonged high frequency vibrations at the point of the animal and that emits an individually distinctive acoustic signal when sound production of the tagged animal is detected. This coded signal can then be recorded on nearby acoustic listening stations and subsequently decoded to allow for identifying the sounds generated by tagged fish. Field experiments with this tag has demonstrated a range of up to 250m, which likely exceeds the range of detection of most fish and invertebrate calls.

The project developed a variety of different configurations (including housing, electronics, battery packs, and other components) for each tag that facilitates deployments on a range of different fish, from large, free-swimming tags where implantable acoustic tags are routinely deployed to track animal movement, to smaller fish and invertebrates where tags are attached with sutures or Velcro harnesses. Combined lab and field experiments allowed us to verify and quantify the accelerometer signals associated with sound production in species as diverse as American lobster (using subtle pulsed sounds) and sea robin (using loud tonal sounds) and showed that the general approach of using high sample rate accelerometers to detect vibrations associated with sound production generalizes well to different physiological sound production mechanisms. In addition to detecting animal sounds, subsequent follow-up experiments also showed the potential for these tags to quantify in-situ exposure levels of loud underwater noise events, such as those associated with pile driving from offshore wind construction. While more work is needed to fine-tune the trade-offs in pre-processing and recording settings for such applications, this might become an important tool for individual-based studies of how fish and invertebrates respond to marine noise events.

All of the technology here, from circuit board designs, tag firmware, programming and offload software, and a variety of 3D-printed housings have been made available under an open-source license on GitHub in the hopes that this will enable wide uptake of these approaches.

This project provided a range of diverse broader impacts to society. These new technologies will create new opportunities for discovering the natural acoustic repertoire of fish and invertebrates, thus in turn opening up opportunities for cheap, large-scale acoustic monitoring of such species and ultimately the ecosystems that they inhabit. Many coral reef ecosystems in particular has been degraded the last decade as a result of ocean warming and other anthropogenic impacts such as eutrophication, overfishing and ocean acidification. However, outputs from this project can also include monitoring and density estimation of commercially important soniferous fishes and invertebrates such as American lobster, cod, or pollock, among others. Thus, results from this project can benefit a wide range of groups from scientists through conservationists and managers, and ultimately also provide data for policy-makers. The project has further provided training and research opportunities for a postdoc, 3 PhD students (including 2 under-represented minorities), and 4 undergraduate researchers.


Last Modified: 11/23/2022
Modified by: Aran Mooney
